name: Civic Tech Vancouver Event #1 | Guest Speaker: Geoffrey Daniel
description:
You're invited to Civic Tech Vancouver’s first event. Free and open to all, this meetup will bring together people from all walks of life to connect, learn, share and collaborate. This first event we’ll be setting the direction of the group for the weeks and months to come.

We’re not the first group like this. There are already civic tech communities in places like Toronto, Ottawa, and Edmonton. We’re inspired by what those groups are doing to bring together people over a common interest in civic issues, looking at them together through the lens of tech. We’re excited to get things moving here in Vancouver.

You do not need to be a ‘techie’ to attend. Everyone is welcome to participate and contribute to civic good through technology, data, design, policy, advocacy and citizen engagement. Join us!

To help kick us off, Geoffrey Daniel, a civil servant turned Digital Strategist for Yellow Pencil, will be giving a talk:

We Need Us: The Public Sector Needs Help, Likely Yours
Geoffrey shares from his experience working with municipal governments for over 15 years. Having worked within large bureaucracies for so long, he’ll be offering us some insight into what the decision making process can look like, and what we can do from our end as citizens to help encourage our brothers and sisters working in government.

Agenda:

6:30pm - Doors Open

7pm - Welcome, Civic Tech YVR Introductions

7:15-7:45pm - Geoffrey Daniel - , Q&A

7:45-8:00pm - Refreshment Break

8:00-8:30pm - Breakout Ideation Sessions

8:30-9pm - Wrap Up & Announcements

name: #2: Vancouver Open Data w/ Rob DeFilippi
description:
You are invited to Civic Tech Vancouver’s second event. Free and open to all, this meetup will bring together people from all walks of life to connect, learn, share, and collaborate. This second event will be more hands on (though optional) for attendees looking to sharpen their skills in locating and working with data related to issues they care about. Attendees are also more than welcome to attend and observe the techniques we’ll be working through during the event.

You do not need to be a ‘techie’ to attend. Everyone is welcome to participate and contribute to civic good through technology, data, design, policy, advocacy, and citizen engagement. Join us!

--

Opening Speaker: Dan Piecuch

Opening the night, Dan will share a project that uses data publicly to drive change.

Dan has worked in both public and private organizations for over 8 years where the goal was the same; leveraging data to drive action.

Working for Vancouver Coastal Health Authority, he utilized healthcare data to optimize surgery wait times, provide better care to patients, and the creation of edwaittimes.ca -- a public-facing resource that arms the public with data on how long it will take to see a physician.

Today, he works for Hootsuite as the Data Analytics and Governance Manager and is tasked to help build out their data foundation to serve customers with improved insights.

Keynote Speaker: Robert Defilippi

Robert will share with us a glimpse of his role as a Data Analyst -- by introducing his process for accessing, cleaning (munging/wrangling), and visualizing data using Vancouver open data sets.

If you want to participate fully for the evening, please bring your laptop. All of the software and datasets will be provided ahead of time, and are free.

Robert is a full time analyst at a startup in Vancouver, and a part time chef everywhere else. He started his career as a consultant after he finished his masters in economics, but soon moved into the tech industry. Previously an instructor at Brainstation for their Data Analytics class, he is usually found at a coffee shop on Main St. working on R or reading a cookbook.

In this event, Robert will be going over how to wrangle/munging raw datasets, to get useful information out of them, and finally provide a tutorial on vis. If you’re new to public datasets (or data analysis) and want to know how people get valuable business intelligence out of seemingly endless row of data, you should come.

All the tools, apps, and data used, will be public and free to access. All that is needed will be a laptop, Google account, and an internet connection.

--

Agenda:

6:30pm - Doors Open

7pm - Welcome, Civic Tech YVR Introductions and Grouping

7:05-7:15pm - Dan Piecuch

7:15-7:45pm - Robert Defilippi + Q&A

7:45-8:00pm - Break

8:00-8:45pm - Hands on Workshop

8:45-8:55pm - Wrap Up & Announcements

9pm - Event Ends

name: Civic Tech Vancouver Event #3 | Community Workshopping
description:
You are invited to Civic Tech Vancouver’s third meetup. We’re going to hear from inspirational people from the community working on projects in the civic tech space, then workshop the future of the city together with members’ projects in mind. This event will begin with two lightning talks on community projects that use technology for civic good. Then, we will move into a share and tell-styled format where the floor will be yours! Do you have a community project that needs support? We want to hear from you.

Not quite ready to share? Attendees are more than welcome to attend and observe, as well as meet fellow community members interested in contributing to civic good through technology, data, design, policy, advocacy, and citizen engagement -- join us!

Agenda:

6:30pm - Doors Open
7pm - Welcome, Civic Tech YVR Introductions
7:10-7:40pm - Lightning Talks: Maryam Khezrzadeh & Orton Mak with Q&A
7:40-8:40pm - Community Workshopping & Refreshments
8:40-8:50pm - Wrap Up & Announcements
9pm - Event Ends

name: Meetup #4 | Smart Cities Challenge with City of Vancouver + City of Surrey
description:
We're excited to be partnering with the City of Vancouver and City of Surrey for Civic Tech Vancouver Meetup #4!
---
At this meetup, you will be able to participate in a facilitated workshop to give your input and ideas to the City of Vancouver and City of Surrey on what should go into the Smart Cities Challenge plan. What are some challenges the City should be working on? What would you like to see different in the City? How you would begin to approach some of these challenges? What solutions seem possible? This meetup is free, inclusive, and open to the public. Venue: City of Vancouver's pop-up Engagement Lab at 511 W Broadway.
---
What is the Smart Cities Challenge?
- The Smart Cities Challenge is a competition open to all municipalities, local or regional governments, and Indigenous communities (First Nations, Inuit, and MÃ©tis) across Canada.
- This Challenge will empower communities across the country to address local issues their residents face through new partnerships, using a smart cities approach.
- A smart cities approach means achieving meaningful outcomes for residents through the use of data and connected technology. This approach can be adopted by any community, big or small.
- Finalists will receive support to develop their smart cities proposals. Winning communities will be awarded with prize money to help implement them.
https://impact.canada.ca/en/challenges/smart-cities
---
The City of Vancouver and the City of Surrey are partnering to compete for $50 million in the Government of Canada’s Smart Cities Challenge. The competition recognizes Canadian cities that use data and connected technology to address local issues. A winning submission for Vancouver and Surrey has the potential to improve all aspects of livability and opportunity in our cities and our region: how we move around and communicate, our environment, and more.
http://www.smartertogether.ca
---
Agenda
6:30pm:
- Doors open
7-7:40pm:
- Intro to Civic Tech YVR
- Presentation from City of Vancouver and City of Surrey + Q&A
7:40-9pm:
- Facilitated workshop for community members to ideate on the Smart Cities Challenge

name: Civic Tech Vancouver Meetup #5 - Panel on Digital Government Movement

venue.name: Emily Carr University of Art + Design

description:
Come learn about the Canadian (& Global) Government Digital Movement from our inspiring panel of civic technologists for Civic Tech Vancouver Meetup #5

---

Panel Host:
Katherine Benjamin, Ontario Digital Service

Panellists:
Honey Dacanay, Ontario Digital Service
Tadhg Healy, City of Vancouver
Roger Oldham, Independent & former CDO at UK Ministry of Justice

---

Agenda:

The event opens at 7pm, and the structured program begins at 7:15.

7:15-7:30 Introduction to digital government
7:30-8:30 Panel presentations and discussion
8:30- 9:00 Networking

---

Parking and Directions:

Parking at ECUAD
- You cannot park in the monthly ECUAD lots (not for public use)
- Available lots: West Lot, Easy Park, metered City of Vancouver road parking Car share
Evo cars are available in the Westpark parking lot east of the Centre for Digital Media. Transit
The Emily Carr campus is centrally located between two Skytrain stations. It’s a 13 minute walk from Main Street/Science World station on the Expo line, and a 12 minute walk from VCC Clark on the Millennium line.

name: Civic Tech Vancouver Meetup #6: Project Jam Night
description:
Civic Tech Vancouver #5 is going to be our first Project Jam Night! We'll start off the evening with our usual introductions, but the rest of the time is up to you: talk to some like-minded folks in the community and ask if they've got any cool civic tech project ideas. If you'd like some idea of what civic tech projects might look like, start by checking out the challenges from CodeAcross Toronto:
http://civictech.ca/codeacross-2018/
http://civictech.ca/codeacross-toronto-2017/

---

What to bring:
Curiousity, and a laptop / paper & pen / vessel for creativity and ideas

Agenda:
Doors are open at 6:30pm
Event opens at 7pm with a short introduction
Open time begins at 7:15

Parking:
Affordable short-term parking close to the main buildings is available. There's also free parking on the street.

Transit:
TransLink, Metro Vancouver's transit authority, has both SkyTrain and bus service to the Centre. We are a 10-minute walk from the Main Street-Science World and the VCC-Clark SkyTrain stations, as well as close to the #84 VCC/UBC, #03 Main, #08 Fraser, #19 Kingsway or the #22 Knight St. bus routes. For more information on TransLink and trip-planning, please visit the TransLink website.

name: Civic Tech Vancouver #7: Open Project Night
description:
--- Format ---

Following up from our first project night in March, we’re going to have another open night to work on projects. There’ll be some free snacks, space to work together, a TV, and a whiteboard.

Bring a laptop or whatever creative tools you like to use.

--- Projects ---

For some of us in the organizing team, the project we’ll be working on will simply be creating a website for Civic Tech Vancouver and making sure people have the ability to learn about us and how they can get involved.

Leave a comment on the meetup page if you have a project you want to work on. Write a short description and some suggestions for what skillsets you need so that others know how to help.
how_to_find_us: When you get to 55 Water St, buzz 300 at the door, and take the elevator up to the 3rd floor. Don’t use the stairs, just use the elevator. Trust me.

name: Civic Tech Vancouver #8: Open Project Night
description:
Civic Tech Vancouver Meetup #8 will be an opportunity for our community members to work on civic tech projects together. Whether you have an existing project idea or want to contribute to someone else's, everyone is welcome. You don't have to be a "techie" to attend!

There’ll be some free snacks, space to work together, a screen, and a whiteboard. Bring a laptop or whatever creative tools you like to use.

--- Projects ---

For some of us in the organizing team, the project we’ll be working on will simply be creating a website for Civic Tech Vancouver and making sure people have the ability to learn about us and how they can get involved.

Leave a comment on the meetup page if you have a project you want to work on. Write a short description and some suggestions for what skillsets you need so that others know how to help.

name: #10: Open House w/ Code For Canada
description:
You're invited next week to come hang out with the community and some special guests to learn about civic tech and Code For Canada. Anybody with an interest in technology and civic issues should come hang out – don't worry, you don't need to know how to code!

A message from Code For Canada:
Code for Canada (https://codefor.ca/) is a national nonprofit that connects government innovators with the tech and design community to improve life for Canadians.

We believe the best organizations work in the open! Our regular Open Houses are an opportunity for the public to meet our team, learn more about our programs and find out how to get involved in Canada's growing civic tech movement.

Code for Canada is partnering with Civic Tech Vancouver to host an Open House in Vancouver on June 19. It’s an opportunity to get to know Code for Canada staff and learn about our exciting 2018 Fellowship (http://codefor.ca/fellowship/), which embeds web developers, UX designers and product managers into government departments to work on things that matter.

Our Open Houses include a short presentation from Code for Canada, followed by informal networking. Light snacks will be served.

We hope to see you there!

name: CivicTech YVR #11 | Increasing Civic Engagement
description:
Welcome to Civic Tech Vancouver’s 11th meetup! Our 11th event will have two talks from members of our local Civic Tech community, discussing how to increase civic engagement. After our talks, we will open the floor up to you! Anyone looking for support on their civic good project is free to stand up and seek out assistance from the community.

Not quite ready to speak? Not so 'techie'? You're still welcome. Everyone is welcome to participate and contribute to civic good through technology, data, design, policy, advocacy, and citizen engagement.

A big thank you to our venue partner, HiVE: www.hivevancouver.com

---

Agenda:
6:30pm - Doors open
7:00pm - Welcome, Civic Tech YVR introductions
7:10-7:30pm - Veronika Bylicki & Tesicca Truong: Who participates? Changing the narrative
7:30-7:40pm - Q&A
7:40-7:50pm - Break
7:50-8:20pm - Steve Anderson: Full Spectrum Engagement
8:20-8:30pm - Q&A
8:30-8:55pm - Discussion
8:55pm - Announcements
9pm - End

---

"Who participates? Changing the narrative"
Veronika Bylicki & Tesicca Truong

Veronika and Tesicca are the co-founders and co-directors of CityHive, an organization that's on a mission to transform the way that youth are engaged in civic processes, planning, and decision-making in their cities.

Veronika Bylicki is an engagement innovator, community builder and sustainability strategist. A lifelong Vancouverite, she is passionate about creating more sustainable, liveable cities and amplifying the meaningful engagement of citizens, particularly youth, in addressing urban challenges. Veronika is currently a Commissioner on the Vancouver City Planning Commission and Board Member for CityStudio Vancouver. She was awarded as a Top 25 Under 25 Environmentalist in Canada in 2015, has delivered a TEDxYouth talk on Urban Sustainability and was a Social Innovation Fellow at RADIUS SFU.

Tesicca Truong is a sustainability activist, a serial changemaker, and an engagement innovator. Her passions lie at the intersection of youth empowerment, citizen engagement, and resilience building. She kick-started Vancouver Youth4Tap and co-founded the Vancouver School Board Sustainability Conference. She has served on the Mayor’s Engaged City Task Force, the Simon Fraser Student Society, SFU Senate, and as board chair of Sustainable SFU. For her work, she was awarded both the President’s Leadership in Sustainability Award from SFU and Vancouver’s Greenest City Leadership Award in 2015. Tesicca has also been named on Corporate Knight’s Top 30 Sustainability Leaders under 30 in 2016, the North American Association for Environmental Education’s Top 30 under 30 in 2016, and twice on the Starfish Canada’s Top 25 Under 25 Environmentalist in 2013 and 2014.

"Full Spectrum Engagement"
Steve Anderson

Steve will be discussing Full Spectrum Engagement, a framework of five key principles of engagement, and practical tactics, that can help effectively activate community power, target decision-makers and win campaigns.

Steve Anderson is the co-founder and chief strategist for New/Mode -- a values-based enterprise that provides targeted online engagement tools. He is recognized around the world as a leader in strategies for civic engagement, advocacy and crowdsourcing. He is also a well-known open Internet advocate. Prior to New/Mode, Steve founded and led the award winning international civic engagement organization OpenMedia to “use the network power of the open Internet to protect the open Internet.” He grew the organization from a small local mailing list to over a million supporters worldwide. OpenMedia has led some of the largest online campaigns in the world. Steve’s experience on the frontiers of online campaigning and engagement led him to found New/Mode as a means to support the world’s most important causes and rebalance democratic decision-making in favour of people and sustainable communities.

name: Civic Tech YVR #12 | Community Potluck
description:
Welcome to Civic Tech Vancouver’s 12th meetup! For our 12th event, we're switching things up and keeping things social with a Community Potluck. Come hang out with Civic Tech community members and get to know one another while enjoying the outdoors and breaking bread together.

Join us from 6:30-9pm at Sunset Beach Park. Both new and returning Civic Tech members are welcome. Bring a friend!

What to bring:
- Yourself
- A food/platter to share with the group
- Any ideas/questions/etc you have about Civic Tech

Where to find us:
- Sunset Beach Park. An organizer will be there early on the day of and share the exact location on this Meetup event page.

name: CivicTech YVR #13 | Democracy & Fairness
description:
Welcome back to the 13th Civic Tech YVR meetup! We hope everyone had a great summer, and we're excited to get back into digging into the overlap between technology and public life. This month we're interested in how technology can be used to strengthen democracy.

We're proud to be hosting John Richardson, CEO of Ethelo (and founder of Pivot Legal Society), to demonstrate how the platform his team has been working on can empower teams to make stronger group decisions. Ethelo has both an established platform serving civic institutions and other organizations, as well as a prototype MVP of an Ethereum blockchain-based version of the platform.

After John's talk, the floor is open to all - anyone looking for support for their initiatives is free to share and make asks of the community. There will be ample time for discussion.

If you're reading this and doubting whether you're 'civic' or 'techie' enough, fret not. Everyone is welcome to come listen, learn, and participate at any skill level. We're here to make these topics more accessible. We seek to contribute to civic good through technology, data, design, policy, advocacy, citizen engagement... the list goes on. If any of that is of interest to you, you should come!

A huge thank you to our venue partner, HCMA Architecture + Design! https://hcma.ca/

---

Agenda:
6:30pm - Doors open
7:00pm - Welcome, Civic Tech YVR introductions
7:15-7:45pm - John Richardson: Ethelo
7:45-8:00pm - Q&A
8:00-8:05pm - Break
8:05-8:25pm - Open Discussion
8:25pm - Announcements
8:30pm - End

---

John Richardson, CEO of Ethelo

John Richardson is a social entrepreneur, mathematician, lawyer and technologist. He is the founder and CEO of Ethelo, an online group decision platform. Ethelo is dedicated to using digital technology to advance participatory democracy. Ethelo has been used by tens of thousands of people for policy development, civic planning and democratic engagement. It has been described by the Canadian Government as "an exceptional advance on the state of the art." Ethelo is powered by a set of algorithms that John invented which enable groups to find broadly supported solutions to complex and contentious decision problems.

John's career focus is systemic approaches to social impact. In 2001 he founded Pivot Legal Society, which conducts strategic litigation for marginalized communities. Pivot focuses on creating legal change on issues of police accountability, sex worker and drug user rights, homelessness and mental health. John built and led Pivot for ten years, and it has become one of Canada's leading human rights organizations. A recognized human rights leader and innovator, John was awarded an Ashoka Fellowship for Social Entrepreneurs in 2005.
how_to_find_us: Buzz 0400 when you arrive, and you’ll be buzzed up to the 4th floor.
